question:
Using relevant sketches, distinguish between

(a) solstice and equinox

B. the earth's rotation and revolution

C. parallels of latitude and meridians of longitude
answer:
(a) Equinox and Solstice:

(i) Equinox means equal days and equal nights while solstice means longer days in summer and longer nights in winter

(ii) Equinox occurs on March 21st and September 23rd while solstice occurs on June 21st and December 22nd

(iii) Equinox could be spring or autumn while solstice could be summer or winter

(b) Rotation and Revolution:

(i) Rotation rotation the earth rotates 360° in 24 hours (one day) while it revolve' round the sun in 3651/4 days (one year)

(ii) Rotation causes day night while revolution causes seasons

(iii) The earth rotates on axis while it revolves round the sun along its orbit

(c) Latitude and Longitude:
Latitude runs parallel to the equator while longitude are perpendicular to the equator

(iii) Circumference of latitudes decreases to the poles while longitudes remain constant

(iii) Longitudes measure up to 360° while latitude measure up to 18

(iv) Only the equator is a great circle while two opposing lines c longitude make a great circle

question:
(a) Discuss, using specific examples, any four factors that determine the pattern of movement of ocean currents the North Pacific Ocean

(b) Select any one cold current in the North Pacific Ocean and outline its effects on thE climate of the adjacent coastland
answer:
(a)(i) The Planetary Winds: The westerly winds drag the North Pacific Drift from west to east

(ii) salinity from the area of greater percentage of salinity the water flows to the areas of lowest salinity hence North Equatorial current flows northwards

(iii) Earth's Rotation: As the earth rotates from west to east, it carries the body of water along e.g California current to North Equatorial to Kurosho to North Pacific Drift

(iv) Temperature Difference: The water from higher temperature area flows to areas with lower temperature e.g from Equatorial regions to colder region or the Kuroshio or the North Pacific Drift flows towards the north.

(b)(i) One cold current in the north pacific ocean in California or Kamchatka current

(ii) Effects of the California current

(i) Reduction in temperature

(ii) Little or no rainfall

(iii) Development of coastal fog

question:
(a) Outline any four factors that can influence climate of a place

(b) In what three ways does climate affect man
answer:
(a) Four factors that can influence the climate of a place are:
(i) Latitude
(ii) Altitude
(iii) Continentality
(iv) Ocean currents 

(b) Three ways in which climate can affect man include:

(i) Health;  Humid or damp environment encourages the growth of micro-organisms which cause the diseases of man

(ii) Clothing;. The type and nature of clothing worn by different people in different locations is due to differences in climate. Cold climate requires black and thick dresses while hot climate requires light dresses.

(iii) Building types The type and nature of houses built in different locations is also influenced by the differences in climate e.g hot regions require air-conditioned houses whereas polar regions do not.

question:
Describe desert encroachment under the following headings

(a) causes (b) areas liable (c) effect (d) methods of prevention
answer:
(a) Causes of desert encroachment;

(i) Prolonged drought

(ii) Over grazing

(iii) Deforestation or uncontrolled tree felling

(iv) Bush burning

(b) Areas liable:

(I) Desert margins e.g sahel regions

(ii) Sudan Savannah, e.g Sokoto, Maiducuri

(iii) Extreme northern part of Nigeria

(c) Effects; 

(i) Loss of vegetation

(ii) Changes in climate of the areas

(iii) Loss of agricultural land

(iv) Loss of animals and humans by death

(d) Methods of preservation:

(i) Afforestation i.e planting of trees

(ii) Controlled grazing

(iii) Controlled tree felling/deforestation

(iv) Controlled or legislation against bush burning

question:
(a) Using specific examples, describe any three causes of air pollution

(b) Outline three major effects of air pollution 

(c) Suggest any three ways of controlling air pollution
answer:
(a) Causes of air pollution

(i) Industrial wastes and fumes

(ii) Fumes from exhaust of vehicles and aero planes

(iii) Fumes from minerals works

(iv) Emission of smoke to the atmosphere

(b) Effects of Air Pollution

(i) It may increase or decrease temperature

(ii) Destruction of the ozone layer

(iii) It causes health hazards, e.g lung diseases

(iv) It may cause accident as a result of poor visibility

(c) Ways of controlling air pollution

(i) Education on waste disposal

(ii) Monitoring of air pollution

(iii) Improved technology, e.g waste recycling

(iv) Government legislation on air pollution

question:
(a) Explain any four factors that-determine population distribution

(b) Describe any two types of population movement

(c) What four problems are associated with any one of the types of population movement described in (b)
answer:
(a) Four factors that determine population distribution are; 

(i) Climate: temperature extremes, i.e too high and too low temperature lead to sparse population while moderate temperature leads to dense population

(ii) Relief; Low relief leads to dense population while rugged relief leads to sparse population

(iii) Minerals: Presence of minerals leads to high population while absence of minerals leads to low population

(iv) Soil: Fertile soil attracts dense population while poor soils attract low population

(b) Two types of population movement are:

(i) Rural-Urban Movement

(ii) Urban-Rural Movement

(c) Four problems of Rural-Urban migration

(i) Population pressure on land

(ii) Congestion (traffic, housing)

(iii) Increase in crime wave

(iv) Unemployment

Town Village

question:
Using specific examples, discuss rail transportation in African countries under the following headings

(a) Reasons for construction (b) Problems (c) Solutions
answer:
(a) Reasons for construction of rail transportation in African countries include:

(i) To open up land, good for major crop production e.g Jos, Maiduguri

(ii) To tap resources in Agriculture, mineral, and forest, e.g rail network in Enugu, Jos, Ibadan

(iii) To link important cities and facilitate movement of people e.g Abidjan-Ouagadougou

(iv) To link different regions thus promoting inter-regional trade e.g North and South of Nigeria

(b) Problems of rail transportation include:

(i) Slow speed

(ii) Poor time schedule

(iii) High cost of spare parts and inadequate capital

(iv) Poor management

(iv) Poor standard of coaches

(c) Solutions:

(i) Need for wider gauge and faster coaches

(ii) Improved management

(iii) Construction of double tracks

(iv) Provision of loans

question:
(a) Draw a sketch map of Nigeria and on it locate and name:
(i) the Niger-Benue trough
(ii) the rivers Niger and Benue
(iii) one confluence town
(iv) Bacita and Numan

(b) Describe the commercial production of sugarcane in the Niger-Benue Trough under the following headings:
(i) method of cultivation
(ii) method of harvesting
(iii) economic importance
answer:
(b) Commercial production of sugarcane under

(i) Method of Cultivation: Land preparation is done and small stalks of sugarcane planted. Planting is done around mid-November-April. Water from Niger and Benue are used for irrigation

(ii) Method of Harvesting: Cane stalks are cut few centimetres above the ground. The leaves are later removed. The canes can be cut by machines or cutlasses after which they are carried to market or factory

(iii) Economic Importance:

(i) As raw materials for sugar industries

(ii) Yields revenue to farmers

(iii) Sugarcane is a food item

(iv) It an serve as fodder or cattle

question:

(b) Describe any four factors which have favoured the production of timber in Nigeria

(c) Outline any four problems facing the lumbering industry in Nigeria
answer:
(b) Four factors which have favoured the production of timber in Nigeria include:

(i) Heavy rainfall well distributed throughout the year

(ii) Uniformly high temperatures

(iii) Presence of economic species e.g Iroko, Obeche, etc

(iv) High demand for tropical hardwood

(c) Four problems facing lumbering industry in Nigeria are:

(i) Poor road condition during rainy season

(ii) Depletion of economic trees

(iii) Low level of technology

(iv) Species are not in pure stands

question:
Describe the distinguishing characteristics of either the Western Highlands or the Eastern Highlands under the following heading:

(a) Relief and drainage (b) Agriculture (c) Problems of development
answer:
Western Highlands:
(a) Relief and drainage: Western highland lies between 300-600m. its hottest summit is Idanre Hill. It serves as source for rivers flowing south and north e.g Osun, Ogun, Ose

(b) Agriculture; Agriculture is mainly subsistence; the region a)so produces grains e.g maize, rice, and root crops like yams, cassava etc. Plantation agriculture is also practised, such as cocoa, kolanut, palm produce and livestock farming

(c) Problems of development
(i) Seasonal water supply
(ii) Presence of pests and diseases
(iii) Problems of erosion
(iv) Problems of floods

question:
(a) Highlight any five features of rotational bush fallowing as practised in WestAfrica

(b) State four advantages of this system of agriculture

(c) Outline any four disadvantages of the system
answer:
(a) Five features of rotational bush fallowing are;

 (i) Farmlands are left to fallow after one or two years of cultivation

(ii) Farmers return to the farmland after fallow period of 2-5 years

(ii) It uses simple farm tools It uses family labour

(v) Mixed cropping is usually practised

(b) Four advantages of the system include:

(i) Soil fertility is regained naturally

(ii) It is easy to practice as low technology is required

(iii) Fallow area provides good grazing grounds

(iv) It is cheap as little is spent on labour and other inputs

(c) Four advantages of the system include

(i) It wastes land due to large area required

(ii) It leads to land fragmentation

(iii) It leads to soil erosion when soil is exhausted

(iv) It does not give room for mechanization

question:
(a) Draw an outline map of Africa and on it, locate the
(i) rivers Zambesi, Nile and Zaire
(ii) mounts Cameroun, Drakensberg and Tibesti
(iii) EastAfrican Rift Valley

(b) Using specific examples explain three effects of mountains on the climate of Africa

(c) Describe any four ways in which the highlands of Africa are of economic importance
answer:
(b) Three effects of mountains on the climate of Africa

(i) It lowers the mean annual temperature, e.g East African highlands

(ii) It leads to heavier rainfall on the wind-ward side of highlands, e.g East of Drakensberg

(iii) It leads to scanty rainfall on the leeward side of mountains

(c) Four ways in which the highlands of Africa are of economic importance are:

(i) They provide a rich soil for agriculture

(ii) They serve as a source of minerals

(iii) They can serve to generate H.E.P

(iv) They serve as tourist centres

question:

(iii) one major town in each area

(b) Describe three major characteristics of any one of the climatic types shown on your map

(c) identify any three ways in which natural vegetation has adapted to the climate in the area selected in (b)
answer:
(b) Three major characteristics of Equatorial Climate:

(i) It has convectional type of rainfall

(ii) It has a double maxima of rainfall

(iii) Temperature is generally high (not less than 27°C)

(c) Three adaptation of vegetation to Equatorial climate include:

(i) Trees possess broad leaves for fast water loss

(ii) Development of aerial roots

(iii) Possession of broad stems to encourage water loss.
